Executive Summary</h2>\n<p>This document details the system architecture for a self-charging electric vehicle (SCEV), a revolutionary vehicle designed to arrive home fully charged.  The architecture prioritizes safety, sustainability, and a seamless user experience, aligning with the company's core values.  The system integrates several cutting-edge technologies, including advanced photovoltaic cells, a sophisticated battery management system (BMS), and predictive energy consumption algorithms.  This document outlines the high-level architecture, key components, data flow, and integration strategies to achieve the company's vision of energy-independent and environmentally sound transportation.</p>\n<h2 id=\"system-overview\">2. System Overview</h2>\n<h3 id=\"purpose-and-scope\">2.1 Purpose and Scope</h3>\n<p><strong>System Purpose:</strong> To design, develop, and manufacture a self-charging electric vehicle that maximizes energy harvesting from renewable sources, optimizes energy consumption, and provides a superior user experience.  The SCEV will minimize reliance on traditional charging infrastructure and contribute to a more sustainable transportation ecosystem.</p>\n<p><strong>Business Context:</strong> This system is central to the company's business strategy, aiming to capture a significant share of the emerging market for sustainable and convenient personal transportation.  Success will depend on delivering a safe, reliable, and user-friendly product that appeals to environmentally conscious consumers.</p>\n<p><strong>Scope Boundaries:</strong> This architecture design focuses on the vehicle's self-charging system, battery management, and user interface.  It excludes details of the vehicle's chassis, drivetrain, and other non-core components.  Future iterations of this document will address those areas.</p>\n<h3 id=\"stakeholders\">2.2 Stakeholders</h3>\n<p><strong>Primary Users:</strong>  Individual consumers, fleet operators (delivery services, ride-sharing companies), and urban commuters.</p>\n<p><strong>System Administrators:</strong>  Service technicians, diagnostic specialists, and remote monitoring personnel.</p>\n<p><strong>Developers:</strong>  Software engineers, embedded systems engineers, electrical engineers, and mechanical engineers.</p>\n<p><strong>Business Stakeholders:</strong>  CEO, CFO, COO, CTO, CMO, Board of Directors.</p>\n<h2 id=\"architectural-principles\">3. Architectural Principles</h2>\n<h3 id=\"design-principles\">3.1 Design Principles</h3>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Modularity:</strong> The system is designed with modular components (e.g., photovoltaic array, BMS, energy management unit) to facilitate independent development, testing, and replacement.</li>\n<li><strong>Scalability:</strong> The design supports increased production volume and future technological upgrades.</li>\n<li><strong>Reliability:</strong> Redundancy and fault tolerance mechanisms are incorporated to ensure system reliability and safety.</li>\n<li><strong>Security:</strong> Secure communication protocols and data encryption are implemented to protect vehicle data and prevent unauthorized access.</li>\n<li><strong>Maintainability:</strong>  The system is designed with clear interfaces and documentation to simplify maintenance and repairs.</li>\n<li><strong>Performance:</strong>  Energy efficiency and optimized power management are prioritized to maximize range and minimize energy waste.</li>\n<li><strong>Sustainability:</strong> The design incorporates environmentally friendly materials and manufacturing processes, minimizing the vehicle's environmental footprint throughout its lifecycle.</li>\n</ul>\n<h3 id=\"quality-attributes\">3.2 Quality Attributes</h3>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Availability:</strong>  Target system availability of 99.99% (excluding planned maintenance).</li>\n<li><strong>Performance:</strong>  Real-time energy monitoring and efficient energy conversion.</li>\n<li><strong>Scalability:</strong>  Support for increased production volume and future technological advancements.</li>\n<li><strong>Security:</strong>  Robust security measures to protect vehicle and user data from unauthorized access and cyber threats.</li>\n<li><strong>Usability:</strong>  Intuitive user interface for monitoring energy levels, adjusting settings, and receiving system diagnostics.</li>\n</ul>\n<h2 id=\"system-architecture\">4. System Architecture</h2>\n<h3 id=\"high-level-architecture\">4.1 High-Level Architecture</h3>\n<p>The SCEV architecture employs a layered approach:</p>\n<pre><code>[User Interface Layer]  --  Displays energy levels, settings, diagnostics.\n        ↓\n[Energy Management System (EMS) Layer] --  Controls energy flow, optimizes charging, manages power distribution.\n        ↓\n[Power Harvesting Layer] --  Photovoltaic cells, regenerative braking system.\n        ↓\n[Battery Management System (BMS) Layer] --  Monitors battery health, optimizes charging/discharging.\n        ↓\n[Battery Pack Layer] --  Stores energy.\n</code></pre>\n<h3 id=\"architectural-patterns\">4.2 Architectural Patterns</h3>\n<p>The system utilizes a layered architecture for clear separation of concerns and a microservices architecture for individual components (EMS, BMS) to allow for independent updates and scaling.</p>\n<h3 id=\"system-context-diagram\">4.3 System Context Diagram</h3>\n<pre><code>[External Power Grid] --(Bi-directional Power Transfer)--&gt; [SCEV] --(Data Transmission)--&gt; [Cloud Platform]\n                                                              |\n                                                              v\n                                                       [Mobile App]\n                                                              |\n                                                              v\n                                                    [User]\n</code></pre>\n<h2 id=\"component-design\">5. Component Design</h2>\n<h3 id=\"core-components\">5.1 Core Components</h3>\n<h4 id=\"user-interface-layer\">5.1.1 User Interface Layer</h4>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Purpose:</strong> Provides drivers and administrators with information and control over the self-charging system.</li>\n<li><strong>Responsibilities:</strong> Displays real-time energy levels, system status, charging efficiency, and diagnostics. Allows users to adjust charging settings (e.g., prioritize self-charging vs. grid charging).</li>\n<li><strong>Interfaces:</strong> Communicates with the EMS via a secure CAN bus.  Provides a mobile app interface for remote monitoring.</li>\n<li><strong>Dependencies:</strong> EMS, communication protocols (CAN bus, mobile app API).</li>\n<li><strong>Technology Stack:</strong>  In-car display system, mobile app (iOS and Android), secure communication protocols.</li>\n</ul>\n<h4 id=\"energy-management-system-ems-layer\">5.1.2 Energy Management System (EMS) Layer</h4>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Purpose:</strong>  Manages and optimizes the flow of energy between the power harvesting system, the battery pack, and the vehicle's electrical systems.</li>\n<li><strong>Responsibilities:</strong>  Monitors energy generation from all sources (photovoltaic cells, regenerative braking).  Predicts energy consumption based on driving patterns and environmental conditions.  Allocates power to vehicle systems and optimizes charging/discharging strategies.</li>\n<li><strong>Interfaces:</strong>  Receives data from the power harvesting layer and BMS. Communicates with the user interface layer.  Communicates with the cloud platform for remote diagnostics and software updates.</li>\n<li><strong>Dependencies:</strong>  Power Harvesting Layer, BMS Layer, Cloud Platform, Communication protocols (CAN bus, cellular).</li>\n<li><strong>Technology Stack:</strong>  Microcontroller unit (MCU), embedded software, predictive algorithms, secure communication protocols.</li>\n</ul>\n<h4 id=\"power-harvesting-layer\">5.1.3 Power Harvesting Layer</h4>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Purpose:</strong> Captures energy from renewable sources and converts it into electrical energy for storage in the battery pack.</li>\n<li><strong>Responsibilities:</strong>  Energy harvesting from integrated photovoltaic cells on the vehicle's roof and hood.  Energy recovery from regenerative braking during deceleration.</li>\n<li><strong>Interfaces:</strong>  Connects directly to the EMS via a power conversion and conditioning unit.</li>\n<li><strong>Dependencies:</strong>  Photovoltaic cells, regenerative braking system, power electronics.</li>\n<li><strong>Technology Stack:</strong>  High-efficiency solar cells, regenerative braking system, power inverters, DC-DC converters.</li>\n</ul>\n<h4 id=\"battery-management-system-bms-layer\">5.1.4 Battery Management System (BMS) Layer</h4>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Purpose:</strong> Monitors and manages the battery pack's performance and health.</li>\n<li><strong>Responsibilities:</strong>  Monitors battery voltage, current, temperature, and state of charge (SOC).  Protects the battery from overcharging, over-discharging, and overheating.  Optimizes charging and discharging rates to extend battery lifespan.</li>\n<li><strong>Interfaces:</strong>  Communicates with the EMS and the battery pack.</li>\n<li><strong>Dependencies:</strong> Battery pack, communication protocols (CAN bus).</li>\n<li><strong>Technology Stack:</strong>  BMS controller, sensors, communication protocols.</li>\n</ul>\n<h4 id=\"battery-pack-layer\">5.1.5 Battery Pack Layer</h4>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Purpose:</strong> Stores the electrical energy harvested from renewable sources.</li>\n<li><strong>Responsibilities:</strong> Provides power to the vehicle's electrical systems.</li>\n<li><strong>Interfaces:</strong>  Connects to the BMS.</li>\n<li><strong>Dependencies:</strong> Battery cells, thermal management system.</li>\n<li><strong>Technology Stack:</strong>  High-capacity battery cells, battery thermal management system.</li>\n</ul>\n<h3 id=\"component-interaction\">5.2 Component Interaction</h3>\n<p>Components communicate primarily via a Controller Area Network (CAN) bus for real-time data exchange and control signals.  The mobile app interacts with a cloud-based platform via a RESTful API for remote monitoring and diagnostics.  Asynchronous communication is used for non-critical data updates (e.g., software updates).  Error handling includes redundancy, fault detection, and fallback mechanisms to ensure safe operation.</p>\n<h2 id=\"data-architecture\">6. Data Architecture</h2>\n<h3 id=\"data-model\">6.1 Data Model</h3>\n<p>The data model includes entities for energy levels (photovoltaic, regenerative braking, battery), system status, user settings, diagnostics, and environmental conditions.  Relationships are established to track energy flow and system performance.</p>\n<h3 id=\"data-storage-strategy\">6.2 Data Storage Strategy</h3>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Primary Database:</strong> Cloud-based NoSQL database (e.g., MongoDB) for flexible data storage and scalability.</li>\n<li><strong>Caching Strategy:</strong>  In-vehicle caching for real-time data access.  Cloud-based caching for frequently accessed data.</li>\n<li><strong>Data Backup:</strong>  Regular backups to cloud storage with versioning and disaster recovery capabilities.</li>\n<li><strong>Data Migration:</strong>  Version control for software and database schema to support future updates and upgrades.</li>\n</ul>\n<h3 id=\"data-security\">6.3 Data Security</h3>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Encryption:</strong>  End-to-end encryption for all data transmission between vehicle components and the cloud platform.  Data at rest is encrypted using strong encryption algorithms.</li>\n<li><strong>Access Control:</strong>  Role-based access control (RBAC) is implemented to restrict access to sensitive data based on user roles.</li>\n<li><strong>Data Privacy:</strong>  Compliance with relevant data privacy regulations (e.g., GDPR).</li>\n<li><strong>Audit Logging:</strong>  Comprehensive logging of all system events and data access for security auditing and troubleshooting.</li>\n</ul>\n<h2 id=\"integration-architecture\">7. Integration Architecture</h2>\n<h3 id=\"external-integrations\">7.1 External Integrations</h3>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>External Power Grid:</strong>  Bi-directional power transfer via a dedicated on-board charging unit (OBC) that supports both charging from and discharging to the grid.</li>\n<li><strong>Cloud Platform:</strong>  Secure data transmission for remote diagnostics, software updates, and over-the-air (OTA) updates.</li>\n<li><strong>Mobile App:</strong>  RESTful API for remote monitoring and control of the self-charging system.</li>\n</ul>\n<h3 id=\"internal-integrations\">7.2 Internal Integrations</h3>\n<p>Components communicate via the CAN bus, using standardized automotive protocols.  Asynchronous messaging (e.g., using a message queue) is used for less time-sensitive communication.</p>\n<h2 id=\"technology-stack\">8. Technology Stack</h2>\n<h3 id=\"development-stack\">8.1 Development Stack</h3>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Frontend:</strong>  Custom in-car display system, React Native for mobile app.</li>\n<li><strong>Backend:</strong>  Node.js for cloud services, C++ for embedded systems.</li>\n<li><strong>Database:</strong>  MongoDB (cloud-based).</li>\n<li><strong>Caching:</strong>  Redis (cloud-based and in-vehicle).</li>\n<li><strong>Message Queue:</strong>  RabbitMQ (cloud-based).</li>\n</ul>\n<h3 id=\"infrastructure\">8.2 Infrastructure</h3>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Cloud Platform:</strong>  AWS or Azure.</li>\n<li><strong>Containerization:</strong>  Docker and Kubernetes.</li>\n<li><strong>CI/CD:</strong>  GitHub Actions or Azure DevOps.</li>\n<li><strong>Monitoring:</strong>  Prometheus and Grafana.</li>\n<li><strong>Security:</strong>  AWS or Azure security services, OAuth 2.0 for authentication.</li>\n</ul>\n<h2 id=\"security-architecture\">9. Security Architecture</h2>\n<h3 id=\"security-requirements\">9.1 Security Requirements</h3>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Authentication:</strong>  Secure authentication for user access to the vehicle and mobile app (multi-factor authentication).</li>\n<li><strong>Authorization:</strong>  RBAC to control access to system functions and data.</li>\n<li><strong>Data Protection:</strong>  End-to-end encryption for all data transmission and storage.</li>\n<li><strong>Network Security:</strong>  Firewalls and intrusion detection systems (IDS) to protect against network attacks.</li>\n</ul>\n<h3 id=\"threat-model\">9.2 Threat Model</h3>\n<p>A comprehensive threat model will be developed, identifying potential threats, vulnerabilities, and mitigation strategies.  This will include consideration of physical attacks, cyberattacks, and environmental factors.</p>\n<h3 id=\"security-controls\">9.3 Security Controls</h3>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Preventive Controls:</strong>  Secure communication protocols, access controls, encryption.</li>\n<li><strong>Detective Controls:</strong>  Intrusion detection, security information and event management (SIEM) systems.</li>\n<li><strong>Corrective Controls:</strong>  Incident response plan, system rollback capabilities.</li>\n</ul>\n<h2 id=\"performance-and-scalability\">10. Performance and Scalability</h2>\n<h3 id=\"performance-requirements\">10.1 Performance Requirements</h3>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Response Time:</strong>  Real-time energy monitoring with sub-second response times.</li>\n<li><strong>Throughput:</strong>  High data throughput for seamless communication between components.</li>\n<li><strong>Resource Utilization:</strong>  Optimized resource utilization to maximize energy efficiency.</li>\n</ul>\n<h3 id=\"scalability-strategy\">10.2 Scalability Strategy</h3>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Horizontal Scaling:</strong>  Cloud-based infrastructure allows for horizontal scaling to handle increased demand.</li>\n<li><strong>Vertical Scaling:</strong>  Upgrading hardware components in the vehicle to improve performance.</li>\n<li><strong>Database Scaling:</strong>  MongoDB’s scalability handles increased data volume.</li>\n</ul>\n<h3 id=\"performance-optimization\">10.3 Performance Optimization</h3>\n<p>Continuous performance monitoring and optimization will be conducted using profiling tools and performance testing.</p>\n<h2 id=\"deployment-architecture\">11. Deployment Architecture</h2>\n<h3 id=\"environment-strategy\">11.1 Environment Strategy</h3>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Development:</strong>  Individual component development and testing using emulators and simulations.</li>\n<li><strong>Testing:</strong>  Integration testing and system testing in a simulated environment and on a test vehicle.</li>\n<li><strong>Staging:</strong>  Pre-production testing in a controlled environment.</li>\n<li><strong>Production:</strong>  Deployment to production vehicles.</li>\n</ul>\n<h3 id=\"deployment-process\">11.2 Deployment Process</h3>\n<p>A CI/CD pipeline will be implemented to automate the build, test, and deployment processes.  Blue-green deployments will be used to minimize downtime during updates.</p>\n<h3 id=\"infrastructure-as-code\">11.3 Infrastructure as Code</h3>\n<p>Terraform or CloudFormation will be used for infrastructure provisioning and management.</p>\n<h2 id=\"risk-management\">12. Risk Management</h2>\n<h3 id=\"technical-risks\">12.1 Technical Risks</h3>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Single Points of Failure:</strong>  Redundancy and failover mechanisms will be implemented to mitigate single points of failure.</li>\n<li><strong>Technology Dependencies:</strong>  Open-source components and industry-standard protocols will be used to reduce vendor lock-in.</li>\n<li><strong>Performance Bottlenecks:</strong>  Continuous monitoring and performance optimization will address bottlenecks.</li>\n</ul>\n<h3 id=\"mitigation-strategies\">12.2 Mitigation Strategies</h3>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Redundancy:</strong>  Redundant systems and components will be employed for critical functions.</li>\n<li><strong>Monitoring:</strong>  Real-time monitoring of system performance and health.</li>\n<li><strong>Documentation:</strong>  Comprehensive system documentation and runbooks.</li>\n</ul>\n<h2 id=\"implementation-roadmap\">13. Implementation Roadmap</h2>\n<p>A phased approach will be used, with specific timelines and deliverables for each phase.  This will be detailed in a separate project plan.</p>\n<h2 id=\"appendices\">14. Appendices</h2>\n<p>(Appendices A, B, and C will be added in a later version of this document)</p>\n<p>This architecture design provides a solid foundation for the development of the SCEV.  Continuous monitoring, testing, and iterative improvements will ensure that the system meets the company's vision and customer expectations.</p>\n",

      "value": "<h1 id=\"deploymentarchitecture\">DeploymentArchitecture</h1>\n<p><strong>Generated by scev-self-charging-electric-vehicle v1.0.0</strong><br />\n<strong>Category:</strong> technical-design<br />\n<strong>Generated:</strong> 2025-08-17T09:25:30.333Z<br />\n<strong>Description:</strong></p>\n<hr />\n<h1 id=\"deployment-architecture-document-self-charging-electric-vehicle-scev-project\">Deployment Architecture Document: Self-Charging Electric Vehicle (SCEV) Project</h1>\n<p><strong>Document Version:</strong> 1.0</p>\n<p><strong>Date:</strong> October 26, 2024</p>\n<h2 id=\"deployment-overview\">1. Deployment Overview</h2>\n<p>This document outlines the deployment architecture for the SCEV project, focusing on the deployment of software components related to vehicle management, data analytics, and potentially customer-facing applications.  The physical deployment of the self-charging technology within the vehicle itself is outside the scope of this document.  We will focus on the cloud-based infrastructure and software deployment.</p>\n<p><strong>Goal:</strong> To establish a robust, scalable, secure, and monitorable deployment architecture for SCEV software components.</p>\n<p><strong>Target Audience:</strong> DevOps Engineers, System Administrators, Project Managers.</p>\n<h2 id=\"infrastructure-architecture\">2. Infrastructure Architecture</h2>\n<p>We propose a cloud-based infrastructure using a multi-cloud strategy (e.g., AWS and Azure) for redundancy and disaster recovery.  This will leverage a microservices architecture for scalability and maintainability.</p>\n<p><strong>Components:</strong></p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Multi-Cloud Platform:</strong> AWS and Azure for redundancy and geographic distribution.</li>\n<li><strong>Compute:</strong>  EC2 instances (AWS) and Virtual Machines (Azure) for application servers, databases, and analytics processing.  Containerization (Docker, Kubernetes) will be used for efficient resource management and deployment.</li>\n<li><strong>Storage:</strong> S3 (AWS) and Blob Storage (Azure) for storing vehicle data, logs, and application artifacts.  Database solutions like RDS (AWS) and SQL Database (Azure) will be used for structured data.</li>\n<li><strong>Networking:</strong> VPC (AWS) and Virtual Network (Azure) for secure network segmentation and isolation.  Load balancers will distribute traffic across multiple instances.</li>\n<li><strong>Monitoring:</strong> CloudWatch (AWS) and Azure Monitor for monitoring application performance, resource utilization, and system health.  Centralized logging with ELK stack or similar.</li>\n<li><strong>Security:</strong> IAM (AWS) and Azure Active Directory for access control and authentication.  Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) system for threat detection and response.  Web Application Firewall (WAF) for protection against common web attacks.</li>\n</ul>\n<h2 id=\"environment-setup\">3. Environment Setup</h2>\n<p>We will utilize a multi-environment approach:</p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Development:</strong>  Used for code development, testing, and integration.  This environment will be less stringent on security and performance requirements.</li>\n<li><strong>Staging:</strong>  A replica of the production environment used for final testing and validation before deployment.  Security and performance will be closely monitored.</li>\n<li><strong>Production:</strong> The live environment where the application is accessible to end-users.  Highest security and performance standards are enforced.</li>\n</ul>\n<h2 id=\"deployment-process\">4. Deployment Process</h2>\n<p>We will employ a Continuous Integration/Continuous Delivery (CI/CD) pipeline to automate the deployment process.  This will involve:</p>\n<ol>\n<li><strong>Code Commit:</strong> Developers commit code changes to a version control system (e.g., Git).</li>\n<li><strong>Build:</strong>  The CI system automatically builds the application and runs unit tests.</li>\n<li><strong>Test:</strong>  Integration tests and potentially UI tests are run in the development environment.</li>\n<li><strong>Deploy to Staging:</strong>  The application is automatically deployed to the staging environment.  Further testing and validation occur here.</li>\n<li><strong>Deploy to Production:</strong>  After successful staging tests, the application is deployed to the production environment.  This may involve a blue/green deployment strategy for zero downtime.</li>\n<li><strong>Monitoring &amp; Feedback:</strong>  Continuous monitoring of the production environment provides feedback for future improvements.</li>\n</ol>\n<h2 id=\"configuration-management\">5. Configuration Management</h2>\n<p>Configuration will be managed using Infrastructure as Code (IaC) tools like Terraform or CloudFormation.  This ensures consistency and repeatability across environments.  Configuration data will be stored in a secure configuration management system (e.g., Ansible, Chef, Puppet).  Secrets management will be handled using dedicated services like AWS Secrets Manager or Azure Key Vault.</p>\n<h2 id=\"scaling-strategy\">6. Scaling Strategy</h2>\n<p>The microservices architecture allows for horizontal scaling.  Individual services can be scaled independently based on demand.  Auto-scaling features provided by the cloud platforms will be used to automatically adjust the number of instances based on resource utilization and traffic patterns.</p>\n<h2 id=\"monitoring-setup\">7. Monitoring Setup</h2>\n<p>A comprehensive monitoring system will be implemented using CloudWatch (AWS) and Azure Monitor.  This will include:</p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Application Performance Monitoring (APM):</strong>  Tracking response times, error rates, and other key performance indicators.</li>\n<li><strong>Resource Utilization Monitoring:</strong>  Tracking CPU, memory, and network usage to identify potential bottlenecks.</li>\n<li><strong>Log Aggregation:</strong>  Centralized logging with ELK stack or similar for analyzing system logs and identifying issues.</li>\n<li><strong>Alerting:</strong>  Automated alerts will be triggered when critical thresholds are exceeded.</li>\n</ul>\n<h2 id=\"backup-and-recovery\">8. Backup and Recovery</h2>\n<p>Regular backups of databases and application data will be performed using the cloud provider's backup services.  A recovery plan will be defined, outlining the steps to restore the system in case of data loss or system failure.</p>\n<h2 id=\"disaster-recovery\">9. Disaster Recovery</h2>\n<p>A disaster recovery plan will be developed, outlining procedures to recover from major outages or disasters.  This will leverage the multi-cloud strategy, allowing for failover to the secondary cloud provider in case of a major incident in the primary region.</p>\n<h2 id=\"maintenance-procedures\">10. Maintenance Procedures</h2>\n<p>Regular maintenance tasks will be scheduled and automated, including:</p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Software Updates:</strong>  Regular patching and upgrades of software components.</li>\n<li><strong>Security Audits:</strong>  Regular security assessments to identify and address vulnerabilities.</li>\n<li><strong>Database Maintenance:</strong>  Regular database backups, optimization, and performance tuning.</li>\n<li><strong>Infrastructure Maintenance:</strong>  Regular maintenance of the cloud infrastructure, including patching and upgrades of servers and networking components.</li>\n</ul>\n<h2 id=\"dependencies\">Dependencies</h2>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>adpa-enterprise-framework-automation:</strong> This dependency will need to be integrated into the CI/CD pipeline and managed appropriately through version control and dependency management tools.</li>\n</ul>\n<h2 id=\"security-considerations\">Security Considerations</h2>\n<p>Security is paramount.  The following measures will be implemented:</p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Secure Code Practices:</strong>  Secure coding standards will be enforced throughout the development lifecycle.</li>\n<li><strong>Regular Security Audits:</strong>  Penetration testing and vulnerability scanning will be performed regularly.</li>\n<li><strong>Access Control:</strong>  Strict access control policies will be enforced using IAM (AWS) and Azure Active Directory.</li>\n<li><strong>Data Encryption:</strong>  Data at rest and in transit will be encrypted.</li>\n<li><strong>Web Application Firewall (WAF):</strong>  A WAF will protect against common web attacks.</li>\n<li><strong>SIEM:</strong>  A SIEM system will monitor security events and logs for potential threats.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>This Deployment Architecture Document provides a high-level overview.  More detailed documentation will be created for each component as the project progresses.</p>\n",

The goal is to ensure system reliability, facilitate efficient debugging, and provide a positive user experience.</p>\n<p><strong>1. Error Handling Strategy:</strong></p>\n<p>Our error handling strategy is built on the principles of <strong>fail-fast, fail-safe, and graceful degradation</strong>.  We will prioritize detecting errors as early as possible, preventing them from cascading into larger failures. When failures do occur, the system should enter a safe state, minimizing harm to the vehicle and its occupants.  Finally, the system should degrade gracefully, maintaining essential functionalities while limiting the impact of partial failures.</p>\n<p><strong>2. Error Categories:</strong></p>\n<p>Errors are categorized for better analysis and handling:</p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Critical Errors:</strong>  These halt the operation of a critical system component (e.g., complete failure of the self-charging system, brake failure due to software error).  They require immediate attention and potentially a system shutdown to ensure safety.</li>\n<li><strong>Major Errors:</strong> These significantly impact system functionality but do not pose an immediate safety risk (e.g., loss of connectivity to the smart grid, failure of a non-critical sensor).  They require prompt resolution and may trigger fallback mechanisms.</li>\n<li><strong>Minor Errors:</strong> These have minimal impact on system functionality (e.g., minor UI glitches, temporary network interruptions).  They are logged for analysis and may be addressed in future releases.</li>\n<li><strong>User Errors:</strong> These result from incorrect user input or actions (e.g., incorrect password entry, attempting to perform an invalid operation).  These require clear, user-friendly error messages.</li>\n<li><strong>Hardware Errors:</strong> These originate from hardware malfunctions (e.g., sensor failure, battery malfunction).  These trigger diagnostic procedures and may initiate a safe mode operation.</li>\n</ul>\n<p><strong>3. Error Logging:</strong></p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Centralized Logging:</strong> A centralized logging system will collect all errors from various components.  This allows for easier aggregation, analysis, and correlation of errors.</li>\n<li><strong>Structured Logging:</strong>  Logs will follow a standardized format (e.g., JSON) including timestamps, severity level (critical, major, minor), error code, component name, detailed error message, stack trace (where applicable), and relevant contextual data (e.g., vehicle speed, battery level).</li>\n<li><strong>Log Levels:</strong>  The system will utilize standard log levels (DEBUG, INFO, WARNING, ERROR, CRITICAL) to filter and prioritize logs.</li>\n<li><strong>Retention Policy:</strong>  Logs will be retained according to a defined policy, considering legal and regulatory requirements.  Older logs may be archived for long-term analysis.</li>\n</ul>\n<p><strong>4. Error Reporting:</strong></p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Real-time Monitoring:</strong> The system will continuously monitor its own health and report critical and major errors in real-time to a remote monitoring system.</li>\n<li><strong>Automated Alerts:</strong> Automated alerts will be generated for critical errors, notifying relevant personnel (e.g., via email, SMS).</li>\n<li><strong>Error Dashboards:</strong>  Web-based dashboards will visualize error rates, trends, and other relevant metrics, allowing for proactive identification of potential problems.</li>\n<li><strong>Remote Diagnostics:</strong>  The system will facilitate remote diagnostics, allowing technicians to access logs and perform troubleshooting remotely.</li>\n</ul>\n<p><strong>5. Recovery Procedures:</strong></p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Critical Errors:</strong>  Recovery procedures for critical errors will prioritize safety. This may involve a safe shutdown of the vehicle, activation of emergency brakes, or other safety measures.  Detailed procedures will be documented and tested.</li>\n<li><strong>Major Errors:</strong>  Recovery procedures will aim to restore functionality or switch to a degraded mode of operation.  This may involve retry mechanisms, fallback systems, or manual intervention.</li>\n<li><strong>Minor Errors:</strong>  Minor errors may self-correct or require a simple user action (e.g., refreshing the UI).</li>\n</ul>\n<p><strong>6. Retry Mechanisms:</strong></p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Exponential Backoff:</strong> Retry mechanisms will employ exponential backoff strategies for transient errors (e.g., network interruptions).  This avoids overwhelming the system with repeated requests.</li>\n<li><strong>Maximum Retry Attempts:</strong> A maximum number of retry attempts will be defined to prevent indefinite retries.</li>\n<li><strong>Retry Conditions:</strong>  Specific conditions will trigger retry attempts (e.g., network errors, temporary sensor failures).</li>\n</ul>\n<p><strong>7. Circuit Breakers:</strong></p>\n<p>Circuit breakers will be implemented to prevent cascading failures.  If a specific service consistently fails, the circuit breaker will temporarily stop requests to that service, allowing it time to recover before resuming normal operation.</p>\n<p><strong>8. User Error Messages:</strong></p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Clear and Concise:</strong> User error messages will be clear, concise, and easy to understand.  Technical jargon should be avoided.</li>\n<li><strong>Actionable Advice:</strong>  Error messages should provide actionable advice on how to resolve the error.</li>\n<li><strong>Consistent Style:</strong>  Error messages will follow a consistent style and format.</li>\n<li><strong>Severity Indication:</strong>  The severity of the error (e.g., warning, error) should be clearly indicated.</li>\n</ul>\n<p><strong>9. Monitoring and Alerts:</strong></p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Real-time Monitoring:</strong> The system will be continuously monitored for errors, performance degradation, and other anomalies.</li>\n<li><strong>Threshold-based Alerts:</strong> Alerts will be triggered when predefined thresholds are exceeded (e.g., high error rate, low battery level).</li>\n<li><strong>Alert Escalation:</strong> A clear escalation process will be defined for handling alerts, ensuring that critical issues are addressed promptly.</li>\n</ul>\n<p><strong>10. Troubleshooting Guide:</strong></p>\n<p>A comprehensive troubleshooting guide will document common errors, their causes, and resolution steps.  This guide will be accessible to both technicians and end-users.</p>\n<p><strong>Error Handling Patterns:</strong></p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Exception Handling:</strong>  Appropriate exception handling mechanisms (try-catch blocks) will be used to gracefully handle anticipated errors.</li>\n<li><strong>Defensive Programming:</strong>  Code will be written defensively, anticipating potential errors and handling them proactively.</li>\n<li><strong>Fail-Fast:</strong> Critical errors will immediately terminate the affected process or component to prevent further damage.</li>\n<li><strong>Fail-Safe:</strong> The system will transition to a safe state in the event of a failure, minimizing harm to the vehicle and occupants.</li>\n</ul>\n<p><strong>Logging Standards:</strong></p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Timestamp:</strong>  ISO 8601 format (e.g., 2024-10-27T10:30:00Z).</li>\n<li><strong>Severity:</strong>  CRITICAL, ERROR, WARNING, INFO, DEBUG.</li>\n<li><strong>Component:</strong>  Name of the software or hardware component generating the log.</li>\n<li><strong>Message:</strong>  Clear description of the error or event.</li>\n<li><strong>Context:</strong>  Relevant data (e.g., sensor readings, user input).</li>\n<li><strong>Stack Trace:</strong>  For software errors, a full stack trace will be included.</li>\n</ul>\n<p><strong>User Experience Considerations:</strong></p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Informative Error Messages:</strong>  Avoid technical jargon.  Provide clear instructions on how to fix user errors.</li>\n<li><strong>Visual Cues:</strong> Use visual cues (e.g., color-coding) to indicate the severity of errors.</li>\n<li><strong>Progressive Disclosure:</strong>  Only display relevant error information to the user; avoid overwhelming them with technical details.</li>\n</ul>\n<p><strong>Monitoring and Alerting:</strong></p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Real-time Dashboards:</strong>  Provide real-time monitoring of system health and error rates.</li>\n<li><strong>Automated Alerts:</strong>  Send alerts to appropriate personnel for critical errors.</li>\n<li><strong>Alert Escalation:</strong>  Define an escalation process to ensure timely resolution of critical issues.</li>\n</ul>\n<p><strong>Recovery Procedures:</strong></p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Automatic Recovery:</strong>  Implement automatic recovery mechanisms for transient errors (e.g., network interruptions).</li>\n<li><strong>Manual Recovery:</strong>  Provide clear instructions for manual recovery procedures for more complex errors.</li>\n<li><strong>Rollback Mechanisms:</strong>  Implement rollback mechanisms to restore the system to a known good state if necessary.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>This comprehensive approach to error handling will significantly improve the reliability and safety of the SCEV, providing a robust and user-friendly experience.  Regular reviews and updates to these guidelines will be essential to adapt to evolving needs and technological advancements.</p>\n",

      "value": "<h1 id=\"integrationdesign\">IntegrationDesign</h1>\n<p><strong>Generated by scev-self-charging-electric-vehicle v1.0.0</strong><br />\n<strong>Category:</strong> technical-design<br />\n<strong>Generated:</strong> 2025-08-17T09:22:28.388Z<br />\n<strong>Description:</strong></p>\n<hr />\n<h2 id=\"integration-design-document-self-charging-electric-vehicle-scev-system\">Integration Design Document: Self-Charging Electric Vehicle (SCEV) System</h2>\n<p><strong>Project Name:</strong> SCEV - Self-Charging Electric Vehicle</p>\n<p><strong>Document Version:</strong> 1.0</p>\n<p><strong>Date:</strong> October 26, 2024</p>\n<p><strong>1. Integration Overview</strong></p>\n<p>This document outlines the integration design for the SCEV system, focusing on the interaction between the vehicle's self-charging components (solar panels, regenerative braking, battery management system), the vehicle's onboard systems (TPMS, infotainment, navigation), and external systems (smart home energy management, power grid). The goal is to create a seamless, efficient, and secure system that maximizes energy harvesting, optimizes power consumption, and provides a superior user experience.  A key aspect of this integration is the bidirectional power flow capability, allowing the vehicle to both draw power from and sell power back to the grid.</p>\n<p><strong>2. Integration Patterns</strong></p>\n<p>The following integration patterns will be employed:</p>\n<ul>\n<li><p><strong>Message Broker:</strong> A robust message broker (e.g., Kafka, RabbitMQ) will be used for asynchronous communication between different components and systems. This ensures loose coupling, scalability, and fault tolerance.  This is crucial for handling the potentially high volume of data from various sources.</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>Event-Driven Architecture (EDA):</strong> The system will operate on an EDA model, with various components publishing events (e.g., solar energy harvested, battery charge level, driving conditions) and other components subscribing to relevant events.  This allows for real-time responses and efficient data flow.</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>Publish-Subscribe (Pub/Sub):</strong>  This pattern will be implemented within the message broker, allowing for flexible communication between components without direct dependencies.</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>Aggregator:</strong> An aggregator pattern will be used to combine data from multiple sources (solar panels, regenerative braking, battery) to provide a consolidated view of the vehicle's energy status.</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>Mediator:</strong> A mediator pattern will manage the complex interactions between the vehicle and external systems (smart home, power grid), simplifying the communication and providing a single point of control.</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>Request-Reply:</strong>  Synchronous communication will be employed for specific requests requiring immediate responses (e.g., requesting current battery status from the BMS).</p>\n</li>\n</ul>\n<p><strong>3. System Interfaces</strong></p>\n<p>The following interfaces will be defined:</p>\n<ul>\n<li><p><strong>Vehicle-to-Grid (V2G) Interface:</strong> This interface will handle the bidirectional power flow between the SCEV and the power grid, adhering to relevant communication protocols and security standards.</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>Vehicle-to-Home (V2H) Interface:</strong> This interface will facilitate communication with a smart home energy management system, allowing for optimized charging and potential energy sharing within the home.</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>Internal Vehicle Interfaces:</strong>  Well-defined APIs will govern communication between the self-charging system (solar panels, regenerative braking, BMS), TPMS, infotainment, and navigation systems.  These interfaces will utilize standardized data formats (see Section 7).</p>\n</li>\n</ul>\n<p><strong>4. Data Flow Design</strong></p>\n<p>The data flow will be as follows:</p>\n<ol>\n<li><p><strong>Energy Harvesting:</strong> Solar panels and regenerative braking systems generate energy and send data (energy generated, current, voltage) to the Battery Management System (BMS) via the internal vehicle interface.</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>Battery Management:</strong> The BMS monitors battery charge level, temperature, and other parameters. It publishes events related to battery status to the message broker.</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>Energy Aggregation:</strong> The aggregator component collects data from the BMS, solar panels, and regenerative braking to provide a consolidated view of energy availability.</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>Smart Home Integration (Optional):</strong> The mediator component communicates with the smart home system via the V2H interface, sharing energy status and negotiating power transfer based on home energy needs and grid conditions.</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>Grid Interaction (Optional):</strong> The mediator communicates with the power grid via the V2G interface, negotiating power exchange based on current grid demand and pricing.  This includes selling excess energy back to the grid.</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>Onboard Systems:</strong>  The infotainment and navigation systems subscribe to relevant events (battery level, energy availability) to display information to the driver.  The TPMS independently communicates its data via its own dedicated channel, but this data can be integrated into a broader system overview.</p>\n</li>\n</ol>\n<p><strong>5. Error Handling</strong></p>\n<ul>\n<li><p><strong>Exception Handling:</strong> Each component will implement robust exception handling mechanisms to gracefully manage errors.</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>Retry Mechanisms:</strong> Retries with exponential backoff will be implemented for transient communication errors.</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>Dead-Letter Queues (DLQs):</strong> Failed messages will be directed to DLQs for later analysis and processing.</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>Alerting:</strong>  Critical errors will trigger alerts to relevant personnel via SMS, email, or other appropriate channels.</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>Circuit Breakers:</strong> Circuit breakers will prevent cascading failures by temporarily halting communication with unresponsive components.</p>\n</li>\n</ul>\n<p><strong>6. Integration Points</strong></p>\n<p>Key integration points include:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>BMS to Message Broker</li>\n<li>Solar Panel Interface to BMS</li>\n<li>Regenerative Braking Interface to BMS</li>\n<li>Message Broker to Aggregator</li>\n<li>Aggregator to Mediator</li>\n<li>Mediator to Smart Home System (V2H)</li>\n<li>Mediator to Power Grid (V2G)</li>\n<li>Message Broker to Onboard Systems (Infotainment, Navigation)</li>\n<li>TPMS to Onboard Systems (Independent channel, potential integration with overall system)</li>\n</ul>\n<p><strong>7. Message Formats</strong></p>\n<p>JSON will be used as the primary message format for inter-system communication due to its flexibility and wide adoption.  Specific schemas will be defined using JSON Schema for validation and data consistency.</p>\n<p><strong>8. Integration Security</strong></p>\n<ul>\n<li><p><strong>Authentication and Authorization:</strong>  Secure authentication and authorization mechanisms (e.g., OAuth 2.0, JWT) will be implemented to protect against unauthorized access.</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>Data Encryption:</strong>  Data will be encrypted both in transit and at rest using industry-standard encryption protocols (e.g., TLS, AES).</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>Secure Communication Channels:</strong>  All communication will occur over secure channels (HTTPS, encrypted message queues).</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>Regular Security Audits:</strong>  Regular security audits and penetration testing will be conducted to identify and address vulnerabilities.</p>\n</li>\n</ul>\n<p><strong>9. Performance Considerations</strong></p>\n<ul>\n<li><p><strong>Asynchronous Communication:</strong>  Asynchronous communication will minimize latency and improve overall system responsiveness.</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>Message Queuing:</strong> Message queues will handle peak loads and ensure efficient data processing.</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>Load Balancing:</strong> Load balancing mechanisms will distribute the workload across multiple servers to prevent bottlenecks.</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>Caching:</strong> Caching strategies will be implemented to reduce database load and improve response times.</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>Scalability:</strong> The system architecture is designed to scale horizontally to accommodate future growth and increased data volume.</p>\n</li>\n</ul>\n<p><strong>10. Monitoring Strategy</strong></p>\n<ul>\n<li><p><strong>Real-time Monitoring:</strong>  Real-time monitoring of key metrics (message throughput, latency, error rates, battery status) will be implemented using appropriate monitoring tools (e.g., Prometheus, Grafana).</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>Alerting:</strong>  Automated alerts will be triggered for critical events and performance degradations.</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>Logging:</strong>  Detailed logging will be implemented for debugging and troubleshooting.</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>Analytics:</strong>  Data analytics will be used to identify trends and optimize system performance.</p>\n</li>\n</ul>\n<p><strong>Dependencies:</strong></p>\n<ul>\n<li>Message Broker (Kafka or RabbitMQ)</li>\n<li>Data Integration Platform (optional, depending on complexity)</li>\n<li>Smart Home Energy Management System API (if V2H is implemented)</li>\n<li>Power Grid Communication Interface (if V2G is implemented)</li>\n<li>Security Infrastructure (Authentication, Authorization, Encryption)</li>\n<li>Monitoring and Alerting System</li>\n</ul>\n<p>This integration design prioritizes scalability, reliability, and security.  The use of established integration patterns and technologies ensures a robust and maintainable system capable of handling the complex interactions required for a self-charging electric vehicle.  Further detailed design specifications will be provided in subsequent documents.</p>\n",
      "representation": "storage"

      "value": "<h1 id=\"securitydesign\">SecurityDesign</h1>\n<p><strong>Generated by scev-self-charging-electric-vehicle v1.0.0</strong><br />\n<strong>Category:</strong> technical-design<br />\n<strong>Generated:</strong> 2025-08-17T09:21:01.639Z<br />\n<strong>Description:</strong></p>\n<hr />\n<h1 id=\"security-design-document-self-charging-electric-vehicle-scev\">Security Design Document: Self-Charging Electric Vehicle (SCEV)</h1>\n<p><strong>Project Name:</strong> SCEV - Self-Charging Electric Vehicle</p>\n<p><strong>Document Version:</strong> 1.0</p>\n<p><strong>Date:</strong> October 26, 2024</p>\n<h2 id=\"security-overview\">1. Security Overview</h2>\n<p>This document outlines the security design for the SCEV, focusing on protecting vehicle data, user privacy, and the integrity of the self-charging system.  The SCEV incorporates several interconnected systems: the vehicle's onboard systems (including the self-charging mechanism, battery management system, and TPMS), cloud-based services for data analytics and remote diagnostics, and mobile applications for user interaction.  Security must be integrated at every level.  Our approach adheres to a defense-in-depth strategy, employing multiple layers of security controls to mitigate risks.</p>\n<p><strong>Security Goals:</strong></p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Confidentiality:</strong> Protect sensitive vehicle data (e.g., location, battery status, user profiles) from unauthorized access.</li>\n<li><strong>Integrity:</strong> Ensure the accuracy and trustworthiness of vehicle data and system operations.  Prevent unauthorized modification or tampering.</li>\n<li><strong>Availability:</strong> Maintain the availability of vehicle functions and services, preventing denial-of-service attacks or system failures.</li>\n<li><strong>Authentication:</strong> Verify the identity of users and devices accessing the system.</li>\n<li><strong>Authorization:</strong> Control access to vehicle functions and data based on user roles and permissions.</li>\n</ul>\n<h2 id=\"authentication-design\">2. Authentication Design</h2>\n<p><strong>User Authentication:</strong></p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA):</strong>  Users will authenticate using a combination of methods, such as a password, biometric authentication (fingerprint or facial recognition), and a one-time password (OTP) generated by a mobile app.  This mitigates risks associated with stolen or compromised passwords.</li>\n<li><strong>Password Management:</strong>  Strong password policies will be enforced, including minimum length, complexity requirements, and regular password changes.  Password complexity will be enforced.</li>\n<li><strong>Account Lockout:</strong>  After multiple failed login attempts, the user account will be temporarily locked to prevent brute-force attacks.</li>\n</ul>\n<p><strong>Device Authentication:</strong></p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Secure Boot:</strong>  The vehicle's onboard systems will use secure boot to ensure that only authorized software is loaded during startup, preventing unauthorized code execution.</li>\n<li><strong>Hardware Security Modules (HSMs):</strong>  Sensitive cryptographic keys and secrets will be stored in tamper-resistant HSMs to protect against physical attacks.</li>\n<li><strong>Certificate-Based Authentication:</strong>  Communication between the vehicle and cloud services will be secured using digital certificates and mutual authentication.</li>\n</ul>\n<h2 id=\"authorization-framework\">3. Authorization Framework</h2>\n<p><strong>Role-Based Access Control (RBAC):</strong>  Access to vehicle functions and data will be controlled using RBAC.  Users will be assigned roles (e.g., owner, driver, service technician) with specific permissions.</p>\n<p><strong>Least Privilege:</strong>  Users will only be granted the minimum necessary permissions to perform their tasks.</p>\n<p><strong>Access Control Lists (ACLs):</strong>  ACLs will be used to define access permissions for specific data and system resources.</p>\n<p><strong>Data Segmentation:</strong>  Sensitive data will be segmented and isolated to limit the impact of potential breaches.</p>\n<h2 id=\"data-protection\">4. Data Protection</h2>\n<p><strong>Data Encryption:</strong></p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>In-Transit Encryption:</strong>  All communication between the vehicle, mobile app, and cloud services will be encrypted using TLS 1.3 or a higher standard.</li>\n<li><strong>At-Rest Encryption:</strong>  Sensitive data stored on the vehicle and in the cloud will be encrypted using strong encryption algorithms (e.g., AES-256).</li>\n<li><strong>Data Masking and Anonymization:</strong>  For non-critical data, data masking and anonymization techniques will be used to protect privacy.</li>\n</ul>\n<p><strong>Data Minimization:</strong>  The SCEV will only collect and store the minimum necessary data to provide its functions.</p>\n<p><strong>Data Retention Policy:</strong>  A clear data retention policy will be defined to specify how long data is stored and when it is deleted.</p>\n<p><strong>Compliance with Data Privacy Regulations:</strong>  The SCEV will comply with relevant data privacy regulations, such as GDPR, CCPA, and others.</p>\n<h2 id=\"network-security\">5. Network Security</h2>\n<p><strong>Secure Communication Channels:</strong>  All communication between vehicle systems, cloud services, and mobile apps will use secure protocols (e.g., HTTPS, MQTT over TLS).</p>\n<p><strong>Firewall:</strong>  A firewall will be implemented on the vehicle and cloud infrastructure to control network traffic and prevent unauthorized access.</p>\n<p><strong>Intrusion Detection/Prevention Systems (IDS/IPS):</strong>  IDS/IPS will be deployed to monitor network traffic for malicious activity and prevent attacks.</p>\n<p><strong>Network Segmentation:</strong>  The vehicle's network will be segmented to isolate critical systems from less critical ones, limiting the impact of potential breaches.</p>\n<p><strong>Wireless Security:</strong>  If wireless communication is used for the self-charging system, it will be secured using strong encryption protocols (e.g., WPA3).</p>\n<h2 id=\"security-controls\">6. Security Controls</h2>\n<p><strong>Secure Coding Practices:</strong>  Secure coding standards will be enforced throughout the development lifecycle to minimize vulnerabilities.</p>\n<p><strong>Regular Security Audits:</strong>  Regular security audits will be conducted to identify and address vulnerabilities.</p>\n<p><strong>Vulnerability Scanning:</strong>  Automated vulnerability scanning tools will be used to identify and mitigate potential security risks.</p>\n<p><strong>Penetration Testing:</strong>  Penetration testing will be performed to evaluate the effectiveness of security controls.</p>\n<p><strong>Security Awareness Training:</strong>  Employees will receive regular security awareness training to educate them about security threats and best practices.</p>\n<h2 id=\"threat-modeling\">7. Threat Modeling</h2>\n<p>A threat modeling exercise will be conducted to identify potential threats and vulnerabilities.  This will involve analyzing the SCEV's architecture and identifying potential attack vectors.  The results will inform the design and implementation of security controls.  We will use a combination of threat modeling methodologies, including STRIDE and PASTA.  Specific threats will include:</p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Data breaches:</strong> Unauthorized access to sensitive vehicle data.</li>\n<li><strong>Denial-of-service (DoS) attacks:</strong>  Disruption of vehicle functions or services.</li>\n<li><strong>Man-in-the-middle (MitM) attacks:</strong>  Interception of communication between the vehicle and other systems.</li>\n<li><strong>Software vulnerabilities:</strong>  Exploitation of software flaws to gain unauthorized access or control.</li>\n<li><strong>Physical attacks:</strong>  Tampering with vehicle hardware to gain unauthorized access.</li>\n<li><strong>Supply chain attacks:</strong>  Compromise of components or software during the manufacturing process.</li>\n</ul>\n<h2 id=\"security-testing-strategy\">8. Security Testing Strategy</h2>\n<p>A comprehensive security testing strategy will be implemented, including:</p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Static Application Security Testing (SAST):</strong>  Analysis of source code to identify vulnerabilities.</li>\n<li><strong>Dynamic Application Security Testing (DAST):</strong>  Testing of the running application to identify vulnerabilities.</li>\n<li><strong>Software Composition Analysis (SCA):</strong>  Identifying and managing vulnerabilities in third-party components.</li>\n<li><strong>Penetration Testing:</strong>  Simulating real-world attacks to assess the effectiveness of security controls.</li>\n<li><strong>Fuzz Testing:</strong>  Providing invalid or unexpected inputs to identify vulnerabilities.</li>\n</ul>\n<h2 id=\"incident-response-plan\">9. Incident Response Plan</h2>\n<p>An incident response plan will be developed to guide the company's response to security incidents.  This plan will include procedures for detection, containment, eradication, recovery, and post-incident activity.  The plan will define roles and responsibilities, communication protocols, and escalation procedures.</p>\n<h2 id=\"compliance-requirements\">10. Compliance Requirements</h2>\n<p>The SCEV will comply with all relevant security and privacy regulations, including:</p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>GDPR (General Data Protection Regulation):</strong>  For data protection in the European Union.</li>\n<li><strong>CCPA (California Consumer Privacy Act):</strong>  For data protection in California.</li>\n<li><strong>ISO 27001:</strong>  For information security management systems.</li>\n<li><strong>Automotive cybersecurity standards (e.g., ISO/SAE 21434):</strong>  Specific automotive cybersecurity requirements.</li>\n<li><strong>Relevant national and regional regulations:</strong>  Other applicable regulations.</li>\n</ul>\n<h2 id=\"security-monitoring\">Security Monitoring</h2>\n<p>Continuous security monitoring will be implemented to detect and respond to security threats.  This will involve:</p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Security Information and Event Management (SIEM):</strong>  Centralized logging and analysis of security events.</li>\n<li><strong>Intrusion Detection/Prevention Systems (IDS/IPS):</strong>  Real-time monitoring of network traffic for malicious activity.</li>\n<li><strong>Vulnerability Management:</strong>  Regular scanning and patching of vulnerabilities.</li>\n<li><strong>Security Auditing:</strong>  Regular review of security logs and system configurations.</li>\n<li><strong>Compliance Monitoring:</strong>  Regular audits to ensure compliance with relevant regulations.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>This document provides a high-level overview of the security design for the SCEV.  Further details will be provided in subsequent design specifications.  This document will be updated as the project progresses and new information becomes available.</p>\n",

System Purpose and Scope:</strong></p>\n<p>The purpose of this system is to design and implement a self-charging electric vehicle (SCEV) that utilizes renewable energy sources to maintain a full charge, minimizing reliance on external charging infrastructure.  The system's scope encompasses the design and integration of the self-charging mechanism, energy management system, user interface, and necessary vehicle modifications.  This specification focuses on the core self-charging system, excluding aspects like vehicle chassis design, motor control, and other standard EV components.</p>\n<p><strong>2. System Architecture:</strong></p>\n<p>The SCEV system architecture comprises three major subsystems:</p>\n<ul>\n<li><p><strong>Energy Harvesting Subsystem:</strong> This subsystem is responsible for capturing renewable energy.  The primary energy source is currently envisioned as solar panels integrated into the vehicle body, but future iterations may incorporate regenerative braking and potentially other sources.</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>Energy Management Subsystem:</strong> This subsystem manages the flow and storage of harvested and battery energy. It optimizes energy distribution to various vehicle systems, prioritizing critical functions and maximizing the vehicle's range.  It includes a Battery Management System (BMS) and a Power Management Unit (PMU).</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>User Interface Subsystem:</strong> This subsystem provides the driver with information about the self-charging system's status, energy levels, and operational parameters.  This may involve a dedicated display screen and integration with the vehicle's infotainment system.</p>\n</li>\n</ul>\n<p>[Insert System Architecture Diagram Here -  A block diagram showing the three subsystems and their interactions]</p>\n<p><strong>3. Module Descriptions:</strong></p>\n<ul>\n<li><p><strong>Solar Panel Array Module:</strong>  Collects solar energy and converts it to DC electricity.  Includes array optimization algorithms for maximizing power output in varying sunlight conditions.</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>Regenerative Braking Module (Future):</strong>  Captures kinetic energy during braking and converts it to electricity. (Not implemented in initial version)</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>Power Management Unit (PMU):</strong>  Manages the power flow between the energy harvesting modules, the battery, and the vehicle's electrical systems.  Includes MPPT (Maximum Power Point Tracking) algorithms.</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>Battery Management System (BMS):</strong>  Monitors and controls the state of the vehicle's battery, ensuring optimal charging and discharging.  Includes cell balancing, state-of-charge estimation, and safety mechanisms.</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>Energy Storage Module:</strong> The vehicle's battery pack.  Specifications will depend on vehicle size and performance requirements.</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>User Interface Module:</strong> Provides real-time feedback on energy generation, storage, and consumption.  Includes visualizations of energy flow and battery status.  Communicates with the PMU and BMS.</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>Pendulum Energy Harvester Module (Research &amp; Development):</strong>  This module, currently under research, aims to supplement the solar energy harvesting via kinetic energy from wheel rotation using a pendulum mechanism. (Details in Section 6)</p>\n</li>\n</ul>\n<p><strong>4. Processing Logic:</strong></p>\n<ul>\n<li><p><strong>Energy Harvesting Subsystem:</strong>  The solar panel array module continuously monitors sunlight intensity and adjusts its operation to maximize power output.  The PMU aggregates power from all harvesting sources.</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>Energy Management Subsystem:</strong> The PMU distributes power based on prioritized needs of vehicle systems (e.g., critical functions first).  The BMS manages battery charging and discharging to maintain optimal performance and safety.</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>Pendulum Energy Harvester Module (R&amp;D):</strong>  This module uses a pendulum suspended within the wheel to generate electricity via electromagnetic induction as the wheel rotates. The pendulum's weight and length are critical parameters, requiring optimization (detailed below).  A mathematical model is required to predict power output based on these parameters, wheel speed, and damping factors.  Optimization algorithms (e.g., genetic algorithms) will be used to determine the optimal pendulum weight and length.</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>User Interface Subsystem:</strong> The UI module receives data from the PMU and BMS to display real-time energy status and system alerts.</p>\n</li>\n</ul>\n<p><strong>7. Error Handling:</strong></p>\n<ul>\n<li><p><strong>Over-voltage/Under-voltage Protection:</strong>  The PMU and BMS will include circuitry to protect against voltage spikes and low voltage conditions.</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>Over-current Protection:</strong>  Fuses and circuit breakers will be used to protect against excessive current draw.</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>Over-temperature Protection:</strong>  The BMS will monitor battery temperature and implement cooling mechanisms or shut down charging if necessary.</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>Fault Detection and Reporting:</strong>  The system will monitor for errors and report them to the driver via the user interface.</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>Safety Shut-off:</strong>  In case of critical errors, the system will automatically shut down to prevent damage or injury.</p>\n</li>\n</ul>\n<p><strong>8. (Value to be determined based on component selection)</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>Battery Life:</strong>  Target minimum lifespan of Z years or W charge cycles. (Values to be determined based on battery technology selection)</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>User Interface Response Time:</strong>  Maximum response time of T milliseconds for UI updates. (Value to be determined based on UI technology selection)</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>Pendulum Energy Harvester (R&amp;D):</strong>  Target minimum power output of P Watts at a wheel speed of Q RPM.  (Values to be determined based on optimization studies)</p>\n</li>\n</ul>\n<p><strong>9. System Constraints:</strong></p>\n<ul>\n<li><p><strong>Weight:</strong>  The added weight of the self-charging system must not significantly impact vehicle handling or fuel efficiency.</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>Size and Packaging:</strong>  The system must be compact enough to integrate seamlessly into the vehicle design.</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>Cost:</strong>  The system must be cost-effective to manufacture and maintain.</p>\n</li>\n<li><p><strong>Safety:</strong>  The system must meet all relevant safety standards and regulations.</p>\n</li>\n</ul>\n<p><strong>10. Version 1.0.0</p>\n<p><strong>1. Technology Stack Overview:</strong></p>\n<p>The SCEV project requires a robust and flexible technology stack capable of handling complex simulations, data analysis, and potentially real-time data ingestion from vehicles.  We will leverage a microservices architecture for scalability and maintainability.  The stack will support both the business planning aspects (website, data analysis) and the embedded systems within the vehicle (energy harvesting optimization).</p>\n<p><strong>2. Frontend Technologies:</strong></p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Technology:</strong> React.js with TypeScript</li>\n<li><strong>Justification:</strong> React provides a component-based architecture, facilitating code reusability and maintainability. It's a popular and well-supported framework with a large community.</li>\n<li><strong>Version:</strong> React 18, TypeScript 5</li>\n<li><strong>Dependencies:</strong>  Material-UI (for UI components), Axios (for API calls), Chart.js (for data visualization)</li>\n</ul>\n<p><strong>3. Backend Technologies:</strong></p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Technology:</strong> Node.js with Express.js and NestJS (microservices)</li>\n<li><strong>Justification:</strong> Node.js provides a JavaScript runtime environment, allowing for consistent development across frontend and backend. NestJS is chosen for building scalable and maintainable microservices, offering a structured approach with dependency injection and modularity.</li>\n<li><strong>Version:</strong> Node.js 20, Express.js 4, NestJS 10</li>\n<li><strong>Dependencies:</strong>  Mongoose (for MongoDB interaction),  Passport.js (for authentication), various utility libraries as needed for specific microservices.</li>\n</ul>\n<p><strong>4. PostgreSQL is used for structured data like business planning documents, financial data, and user accounts requiring ACID properties. This ensures fast and reliable releases and allows for continuous integration and continuous delivery.</li>\n</ul>\n<p><strong>Embedded System (Energy Harvesting Optimization):</strong></p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Microcontroller:</strong>  A high-performance microcontroller (e.g., STM32H7, ESP32-S3) with sufficient processing power and peripherals for sensor data acquisition, signal processing, and communication.</li>\n<li><strong>Sensors:</strong>  Accelerometer, gyroscope, potentially other sensors depending on the design.</li>\n<li><strong>Energy Harvesting Component:</strong>  Pendulum-based electromagnetic generator.</li>\n<li><strong>Programming Language:</strong> C/C++ (for efficiency and real-time capabilities)</li>\n<li><strong>Development Tools:</strong>  Embedded IDE (e.g., Keil MDK, IAR Embedded Workbench), JTAG debugger.</li>\n</ul>\n<p><strong>Dependencies:</strong></p>\n<ul>\n<li><code>adpa-enterprise-framework-automation</code>: This dependency (assuming it's an internal library) needs further clarification to understand its role and how it integrates with the overall stack.
